Well, I'm not entirely familiar with that particular format for Q&A, so I wouldn't know much, but the questions you've been asking for the past few times seem like they'd benefit a lot more with a more debate-type setting.
The way I see Arqade, it doesn't seem to encourage much of a back-and-forth discussion.
Just "here's my answer to the question" and done. Which is why I'd suggest getting onto Discord, unless you'd prefer not to.

"here's my answer to the question" and done can be good, too, though, because people write a thoughtful answer, whereas in a fast-paced chat, people might not have as much patience with detailed analysis. Thing is, on StackExchange, even when answers can be confirmed as true or false (e.g. if they're suggesting code that either does or doesn't work), there are still solutions that can be more elegant than others. E.g. one guy might do in one line of code what takes another guy five lines of code, and he'll get more upvotes for that. And stuff like, "How much memory should I allocate to _____ for optimal performance of my SQL database" can have answers of varying usefulness. Idk, I've been happy with the answers people have given on the werewolv.es StackExchange; it seems like they've offered good insight
Discord also doesn't organize stuff in that convenient format that StackExchange does; it can be harder to search through the archives for relevant old convos, unless you know what keywords to use

basically every argument you can make about strategy in this game, has a counter-argument, because the game tends to gravitate toward an equilibrium. Let's say, for instance, I hit a villager yesterday. If the ratio of village:wolves goes down, then the odds of hitting one the next time the village has to do an (educated or random) guess increases, so it starts to gravitate toward the balance it would've gravitated toward if a wolf had been hit. You're usually only buying, or costing yourself, one night of time whether you make a good or bad decision

it's partly a game of chance. kind of like poker. Is the human element a huge factor? yeah, but you can also analyze what the odds favor in different situations
My experience is that winning is the result of a synergy between players. Random lynches don’t exist so I think random acts in general have a minor role to play.
Even wolf kills are often not random. I usually go for non-talkers N1 and I know some others who do this too.

there are different theories. It's like how people have different schools of thought about whether, when you have a weak hand in poker, you should fold or bet. Some say, you should bet, because the other guy might have a weak hand too and he might fold, and if that happens enough times, it might make up for the losses. The parallel kind of situation in this game is, you can either lynch when you have the opportunity, or you can give the wolves a night kill to allow your side time to try to gather some more information to be able to make a more accurate lynch decision
as time goes on, the likelihood that your seer, GD, etc. are dead, and that the wolves know they're dead, tends to increase
we can look back and say, okay, such-and-such % of games where the GD came out after D3 resulted in a village win
but, then people say, "that could've been different setups, etc."
e.g. maybe one of those games had a vampire, and another just had wolves
the potential is theoretically there to try to figure out, what's optimal
but you'd want to compare apples to apples
a lot of hunches about the players end up being wrong, because innocent behavior can seem sus, and sus behavior can be explained away
